posts.name: Brian Churchwell
posts.cooked: If the Chrome app is deprecated I can’t see how to run Signal on a Chromebook. Is there a roadmap for this?

posts.name: Thomas Bohn
posts.cooked: I would prefer a progressive web application anyway. But I’m in a very small minority who thinks putting multiple browsers on my machine is weird.

posts.name: Russ
posts.cooked: I use a chromebook too so I don’t need Signal Destop but a Chrome app is still necessary.

posts.name: Keith Z G
posts.cooked: Yeah, I often use ChromeOS too and this is a rather annoying downgrade. Gonna have to get folks I know using Riot.im instead I guess . . .

I think it’s difficult to enable end-to-end encryption via a web app, thus the reason for a standalone app on the system.

Right now, your Signal Desktop doesn’t need to phone after registration. both are completely independent.

posts.name: Uliar
posts.cooked: +1 on still supporting Chromebooks

I think it’s difficult to enable end-to-end encryption via a web app, thus the reason for a standalone app on the system.

Actually the real reason why move away from web app is because Google announced it will kill this option on Windows/Linux/MaxOS starting at the beginning of 2018. Chrome OS is the only one still supported. More info: Google Kills Chrome Apps: Here's Everything You Need to Know

Why Electron app? Because there is the least work to do from web app to Electron, so minimal effort.

In my humble opinion OWS will not support web app anymore (it is in deprecated status), because one more platform to support. OWS is focusing on Android and iOS on mobile phones and Windows, MacOS and Linux (currently only APT distributions like Debian, Ubuntu and derivates).

link_counts.title: Google Kills Chrome Apps: Here's Everything You Need to Know

posts.name: Spurgeon Spooner
posts.cooked: When support for tablets is introduced, maybe then we’ll be able to install the Android app on Google Play Store compatible Chromebooks?
Actually, you’re totally right. I think this is the way to go.
Chrome App for Signal has been useful [able to install] because I do not have an administration rights for the computer that I use in school!

posts.name: Keith Z G
posts.cooked: That won’t work, since the Android app essentially assumes it’s the mothership, and has you register/act as an account holder with a phone number. If they add the ability for the Android app to act like the Desktop or Extension app and be a mere connected device, sure. But they’ve said nothing of the sort.
Android app doesn’t run on Chromebooks anyway, at least not on my Acer Chromebook 14 for Work. Play Store says “This app is incompatible with your device.”

posts.name: Matthew Fry
posts.cooked: My wife and I both have chromebooks and Signal has been the primary way my wife and I have communicated while I’m at work. I can still use signal-desktop on my debian crouton but this is probably going to drive my wife away from signal. It was hard enough to get my wife on board let alone my friends who have all abandoned Signal (incorrectly, I might add so they still show up in my contact list). I don’t think it’s possible to know how many people use chromebooks as their daily drivers but my wife and I do and we’re not the only ones. I think the proper way forward for Chromebooks (personally) is a tablet app. It checks all the boxes and maximizes its audience.
Maybe CodeWeavers’ CrossOver on Chrome OS would be a solution? It promises to make most Windows applications run on Chrome OS, so the stand-alone version of Signal Desktop could be used perhaps.
Chromebooks are cheap and used in lots of schools. I think it is important that Chromebook users have access to Signal too.

It will soon be possible to install Signal Desktop on Chromebooks:

Google today announced Chrome OS is getting Linux support. As a result, Chromebooks will soon be able to run Linux apps and execute Linux commands. A preview of Linux on the Pixelbook will be released first, with support for more devices coming soon.

One of Google’s goals this year is to make it possible for developers to code on Chromebooks. Want Chrome OS to run the Linux terminal, Android Studio, Git, Sublime, Vim, or Android Studio? All of that will be possible this year. “Just go to wherever you normally get those apps, whether it’s on the websites or through apt-get in the Linux terminal, and seamless get those apps like any other Linux distribution,” Chrome OS director of product management Kan Liu told VentureBeat.

VentureBeat – 8 May 18

Chrome OS is getting Linux app support

Are you looking to showcase your brand in front of the gaming industry’s top leaders? Learn more about GamesBeat Summit sponsorship opportunities here.  Google today announced Chrome OS is getting Linux support. As a result, Chromebooks will...

link_counts.title: Chrome OS is getting Linux app support | VentureBeat

posts.name: Dan Blah
posts.cooked: Confirming that the instructions listed on the download/install at Signal >> Download Signal for linux work on a Pixelbook in the dev channel, with the Linux (beta) option enabled. It’s not the most straightforward or easiest thing, but does mostly work (no notifications, need to run it from the command line the first time then pin it, etc).

posts.name: Joel Palmtag
posts.cooked:
I asked this same question on the github issue page, and was given an unfortunate response:

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Desktop

Signal Desktop Reporting Upgrade now on Up To Date ChromeOS version

opened 12:48AM - 19 Oct 18 UTC
closed 06:07PM - 19 Oct 18 UTC
xmycroftx

* [X ] I have searched open and closed issues for duplicates ### Bug descript…ion Signal Desktop Users on ChromeOS are receiving an irrelevant Notification that is confusing. ### Steps to reproduce Install Signal on a ChromeOS device Link it to any other device You'll get an upgrade message with a button that isn't relevant to ChromeOS. Actual result: A fresh install of Signal from the latest release on the app store gives a warning that it is out of date, and provides an upgrade button that isn't applicable to ChromeOS. Expected result: Warns a user only if there is a new extension in the Play store, and sends the user to the Chrome App Play Store link. ### Screenshots ![screenshot 2018-10-18 at 5 41 53 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2068691/47191680-94cfb800-d2fd-11e8-8a55-20fac13653be.png) ### Platform info Signal version: Signal-Desktop/0.47.1 Operating System: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; CrOS x86_64 11151.4.0) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/71.0.3578.8 Linked device version: ### Link to debug log https://debuglogs.org/db5d3dd7780935dec31730a9d49ee067cb3e12356ba20ca84e0673a91c7deab9

It is discontinued, and there is currently a staff shortage for someone to work on this.

link_counts.title: Signal Desktop Reporting Upgrade now on Up To Date ChromeOS version · Issue #2805 · signalapp/Signal-Desktop · GitHub

posts.name: Joel Palmtag
posts.cooked: If the stuff in the press is how the product ends up (linux apps on ChromeOS) then it should be pretty seemless in the future :). Until then, there may be a gap in support for CrOS users.

posts.name: Dan Blah
posts.cooked: Truth. Every update from CrOS and Signal-desktop for Linux brings improvements. The app is notably more reliable and usable in CrOS than a month ago.
